choices.D: Review the procurement process to determine the lessons learned in relation to discovering risks toward the end of the process.
choices.A: Develop a security exemption, as the solution does not meet the security policies of the energy organization.
choices.C: Mititgate the risks by asking the vendor to accept the in-country privacy principles and modify the retention period.
choices.B: Require a solution owner within the energy organization to accept the identified risks and consequences.

discussion.content:
How am I reading the first risk incorrectly?

"1. There are clauses that confirm a data retention period in line with what is in the energy organization's security policy."

I keep reading it over and over but it seems like a good thing and not a risk? If the data retention period is in line with the energy organization's security policy... how is that a risk??

comments.content: Stop misleading people. people see your answers and confused and failed the exam, you happy? "The number of users accessing the system will be small, and no sensitive data will be hosted in the SaaS platform"-->I don't think you didn't see that. obviously CompTia indicates the risk is small and acceptable!
Using in-country privacy principles could be a regulatory requirement.

discussion.content:
Maybe: C. Mititgate the risks by asking the vendor to accept the in-country privacy principles and modify the retention period?
These requests are modest. I would think most vendors could accommodate such requests.

questions.question_text:
An infrastructure team within an energy organization is at the end of a procurement process and has selected a vendor's SaaS platform to deliver services. As part of the legal negotiation, there are a number of outstanding risks, including:
1. There are clauses that confirm a data retention period in line with what is in the energy organization's security policy.
2. The data will be hosted and managed outside of the energy organization's geographical location.
The number of users accessing the system will be small, and no sensitive data will be hosted in the SaaS platform. Which of the following should the project's security consultant recommend as the NEXT step?

comments.content: DO NOT LISTEN TO THIS GUY... HE GIVES MISLEADING ANSWERS ALL THE TIME

discussion.content: The obvious answer would seem to be HTTP interceptor. But, it could be possible that the code segment already generated, and emailed, might have been created with an HTTP interceptor, and now the security administrator will need to use a vulnerability scanner for "further security assessment of this issue."

comments.content: I agree obfuscation makes no sense, but not sure about code comments and documentation (option C) being an answer. This is more so to have a historical account of failures and successes for reference and sure it can indirectly improve quality. However, continuous integration (option B) makes more of a direct improvement of quality.

discussion.content:
C/D
Code obfuscation has nothing to do with better code and software performance. The code is obfuscated when you compile it anyway. Use static analysis tools to check for common coding errors and administratively enforce comments and code markup to prevent developers from tripping over each other.

Selected Answer: BD
Going with B. Continuous integration and D. Static analysis tools.

We all seem to agree with D. I think its is also B because the AIO book (p.708) says " By developers continuously performing the integration, code drift is less likely to occur; in addition, this permits functional and security code repairs while the issues are still small, makes for high-quality and more secure software."
I'm with Trap on this one. Only C and D would improve code quality, whereas obfuscation makes no sense.

I'm actually leaning towards D and E. I can see containers helping with the integrity and overall stability of the solution. test it then package it up and push it. there's no running into something on the production server that the app doesn't like.
Thoughts?

F. Code obfuscation - does not make sense. 
Maybe: C. Code comments and documentation

comments.content: I think most everyone agrees it is not F. Code obfuscation.

questions.question_text: A software development company lost customers recently because of a large number of software issues. These issues were related to integrity and availability defects, including buffer overflows, pointer dereferences, and others. Which of the following should the company implement to improve code quality? (Choose two.)

choices.B: Require that employees divulge social media accounts.
choices.A: Utilize insider threat consultants to provide expertise.
choices.D: Perform social engineering tests to evaluate employee awareness.

questions.question_text:
A company's Chief Operating Officer (COO) is concerned about the potential for competitors to infer proprietary information gathered from employees' social media accounts.

Which of the following methods should the company use to gauge its own social media threat level without targeting individual employees?

comments.content:
You could send out a phishing email to group of employees. I don't know if that applies here. 
Maybe you could create a social media account, and ask about company information? You would not be targeting any individuals.
You can't social engineer a group of people, you have to do it one at a time. D would require you to target individual employees. A is the correct answer.

discussion.content: dboy773 D would target a group of employees not individual employees.

Maybe D. Perform social engineering tests to evaluate employee awareness?
The answer: "Utilize insider threat consultants to provide expertise" tells us nothing about the method used to gauge social media threat. It simply suggests "let somebody else do it."
Okay, but do *what* exactly? If "hire somebody else to do the job" is an acceptable answer, why not use that for everything?

comments.content:
You do not have to target individuals in order to perform social engineering tests.
You could send out a phishing email to all employees. You could create a fake social media account, and ask about company information.
The question states: "without targeting individual employees" it can't be D because you would have to target your employees in order to perform social engineering tests. I would say A.

True, i was going to say A but your answer makes a lot of sense. now... what if group social engineering attacks count as individual attacks when counting the number of victims that fell for it though?

questions.question_text: Following a security assessment, the Chief Information Security Officer (CISO) is reviewing the results of the assessment and evaluating potential risk treatment strategies. As part of the CISO's evaluation, a judgment of potential impact based on the identified risk is performed. To prioritize response actions, the CISO uses past experience to take into account the exposure factor as well as the external accessibility of the weakness identified. Which of the following is the CISO performing?

discussion.content: I think it’s B. Exposure factors are used to quantify risk.

comments.content: But it's based on past experience, and not statistical analysis or data-driven likelihood. This is a qualitative assessment for sure. C.
yes, I agree. Never says he is calculating exposure factor, says he is using past experience to account for the exposure factor. That’s qualitative.

discussion.content: C. Qualitative assessment of risk - The CISO is evaluating risk without placing a price tag.
keyword: past experience=Qualitative. Quantitative deals with numbers
A - CISO uses “past experience” was key words here I think

From CompTIA official CASP+ study guide:
Quantitative analysis is based completely on numeric values. Data is
analyzed using historic records, experiences, industry best practices and
records, statistical theories, testing, and experiments. This methodology
may be weak in situations where risk is not easily quantifiable. The goal of
quantitative analysis is to calculate the probable loss for every risk

comments.content:
Qualitative analysis methods use descriptions and words to measure the
likelihood and impact of risk. For example, impact ratings can be severe/
high, moderate/medium, or low; and likelihood ratings can be likely,
unlikely, or rare. Qualitative analysis is generally scenario-based. A
weakness of qualitative risk analysis lies with its sometimes subjective and
untestable methodology. You can also assign numbers between 0 and 9
for exposures and damage potential. However, you do not perform
calculations on the numbers assigned to the risks. The goal of qualitative
assessment is to rank the risks on a scale of 1 to 25, for example

discussion.content: "A judgment on the potential impact" means it's qualitative so it's B

comments.content:
I think you mean 'C'
C. Qualitative assessment of risk
